sections.text: Irene Shen: Hi Armando—this is Irene Shen. Thanks for taking a few minutes. I’ll keep it brief: I work with teams that are trying to get clearer on which customer segments are actually their best customers and how to message to the next segments they want to win. Is now still okay?
Armando Burke: Yeah, I’ve got about five minutes. What’s this regarding?

Irene Shen: Perfect. The product is called Customer_Analyzer. It pulls together signals you already have—CRM fields, onboarding survey answers, product usage events, support tickets, even interview notes—and turns that into two practical things: a fit score for different segments, and positioning recommendations you can actually use in your marketing and sales motions. I noticed Harborloom Textiles has been expanding into a few industries—how are you currently deciding which industries to target next quarter?
Armando Burke: Mostly gut and what sales is hearing. We look at revenue and maybe churn, but it’s not super scientific. We’re also kind of stretched thin right now.

Irene Shen: That’s exactly the situation we built this for—when it’s a mix of anecdotes and spreadsheets and it’s hard to align. One use case we see a lot is prioritizing which industries to target next quarter using retention and support burden signals. So rather than just “which industry has deals,” you can see “which industry sticks, expands, and doesn’t generate tons of support load.”
Armando Burke: Okay. But we don’t have a clean dataset. And honestly we’ve tried dashboards. People stop using them.

Irene Shen: Totally fair. The difference is we’re not trying to be another dashboard. The core output is a set of segment-specific messaging blocks—positioning recommendations—grounded in what your best customers actually say and do. For example: for Industry A, it might generate a value proposition, top use cases, differentiators, proof points you should collect, and even objection-handling. And it packages those as editable blocks like website hero copy, sales deck bullets, and email openers.
Armando Burke: We already have messaging. Marketing has a positioning doc somewhere. Sales has their version. Not sure we need another.

Irene Shen: Makes sense—and I’m not suggesting you throw that out. Where teams usually feel pain is when messaging isn’t consistent by segment, or when you’re moving into a new industry and you’re not sure what to lead with. Customer_Analyzer links each recommendation back to the “why”—the drivers and evidence—so it’s not just AI copy. It will show, “This segment retains 20% better and mentions X outcome in tickets and surveys,” so your team can trust it and edit it.
Armando Burke: Linking to evidence sounds nice, but getting all those sources connected sounds like a project. We don’t have bandwidth for a long implementation.

Irene Shen: Implementation is a common concern. We typically start with just two sources to keep it light—say, CRM plus support tickets—then expand if it’s worth it. The goal is quick signal: which industries are high-fit versus high-support-burden, and what language resonates. If I asked: do you have decent retention info by industry, and can you tag support tickets by customer or industry?
Armando Burke: Retention by industry… kind of. Support tickets are messy. We use Zendesk but tagging is inconsistent. Also, our “industries” in the CRM are not reliable.

Irene Shen: Got it—so the taxonomy is the issue, which would definitely blunt the impact. We can sometimes help by inferring segments from other fields, but if the underlying customer/industry data isn’t stable, that’s harder. What’s prompting the next-quarter industry decision—are you seeing churn in certain segments, or just trying to grow faster?
Armando Burke: We’re being pushed to grow, but we’re also fighting fires. Support load is a big deal—some customers just drain us. But, again, it’s hard to quantify cleanly.

Irene Shen: Understood. In those cases, the “support burden” angle can be really valuable—like surfacing which segments generate the most tickets per active account, or the most escalations, and pairing that with retention. Then the positioning recommendations help you either avoid those segments, or set expectations and handle objections up front with better messaging.

Armando Burke: This all sounds reasonable, but I’m not sure we’re in a place to adopt a new tool. We’re midstream on a CRM cleanup and a website refresh. Adding another platform might be tough politically.

Irene Shen: That’s fair. The last thing I want is to add noise. If you were to do anything here, what would be most helpful: (1) a clearer view of which industries are net-positive—retention vs support burden—or (2) segment-specific messaging your sales team can use without reinventing it every time?
Armando Burke: Probably the first, but again, we’re not ready. And honestly, our biggest issue is internal alignment, not lack of recommendations.

Irene Shen: Internal alignment is exactly what this is meant to support, but I hear you on timing and readiness. Sometimes teams use it as a forcing function—“here’s the evidence by segment”—but if you’re already in the middle of CRM cleanup, you might not get clean outputs yet. Would it be helpful if we set up a longer call with your marketing lead to see if there’s a lightweight way to pilot just CRM + Zendesk, or would that be a distraction right now?
Armando Burke: It would be a distraction. I don’t want to pull marketing into another evaluation. We’re just trying to get through the quarter.
Irene Shen: Okay, that’s clear. Before I let you go: when do you expect the CRM cleanup to be in a better place—next quarter, second half of the year?
Armando Burke: Maybe second half. Hard to say. We’ve slipped on it before.

Irene Shen: Totally understand. What I can do is send a one-page overview of the positioning recommendation output—like what the editable messaging blocks look like, and how they tie back to retention and support signals—so you can bookmark it for later. And I can check back in, say, three months, to see if the timing is any better. Does that work?
Armando Burke: Sure, send it over. But yeah—don’t expect quick movement.
Irene Shen: That’s fine. What’s the best email for you, Armando?
Armando Burke: armando.burke@harborloom.com.

Irene Shen: Great—thanks. I’ll send that one-pager and a short note summarizing the specific use case we discussed: prioritizing industries next quarter using retention and support burden, plus the segment-specific positioning blocks. Appreciate the time today.
Armando Burke: No problem. Thanks.
